title: Types of Sports Betting Explained: Your Complete Guide

overview.data:
With modern sportsbooks offering a wide variety of betting options, it's no longer just about predicting the winner. Understanding the different types of sports bets can significantly improve your decision-making, enhance your betting strategy, and help you identify value in less obvious markets.
This guide covers all major types of bets — from basic singles to complex combinations and sport-specific wagers.

overview.heading: Why Knowing Bet Types Matters
overview.data:
The more bet types you understand, the more strategic your choices can be. It allows you to:
● Explore alternative markets for better value
● Customize your betting to fit specific sports
● Use specialized knowledge to gain an edge over bookmakers
Let’s break down each major category of sports betting.

overview.heading: Core Bet Types
overview.data:
Single Bet
A straightforward bet on one outcome. Examples include:
● A football team to win a match
● A tennis player to win a set
● A golfer to finish first in a tournament
This is the most basic and widely used betting type.
Accumulator (Acca)
An accumulator combines multiple selections into a single bet. All selections must win for the bet to succeed. For example:
● Arsenal (2.0) + Tottenham (2.5) + Liverpool (1.5)
● Total odds = 2.0 × 2.5 × 1.5 = 7.5
Losing just one leg results in a lost bet.
Bet Builder
Similar to an accumulator, but all selections are within a single match. For example, in a football match:
● Team A to win
● Both teams to score
● Over 4.5 cards
All selections must be correct for the bet to win.

overview.heading: Combination and System Bets
overview.data:
Trixie
A bet involving 3 selections, generating 4 bets:
● 3 doubles
● 1 treble
At least two correct selections return a profit.
Patent
Also uses 3 selections, but covers 7 bets:
● 3 singles
● 3 doubles
● 1 treble
Even one correct pick returns something.
Yankee
Uses 4 selections and includes 11 bets:
● 6 doubles
● 4 trebles
● 1 four-fold
Similar bets with more selections include Lucky 15, Canadian, and Heinz.

overview.heading: Region-Specific Bet Types
overview.data:
Moneyline (Common in US Sports)
Bet on who wins a game. Used mostly in NFL, NBA, and MLB.
Example:
● Team A: -180 (You bet $180 to win $100)
● Team B: +160 (You bet $100 to win $160)
This is equivalent to the “match odds” market in European betting.
Point Spread
Levels the playing field by giving the underdog a point advantage.
Example:
● Team A: -4.5 points
● Team B: +4.5 points
You win if your selection covers the spread.

overview.heading: Advanced Bet Types
overview.data:
Handicap Betting
Similar to point spreads but used globally in sports like football, tennis, rugby, and snooker.
One team is given a virtual advantage to balance the odds.
Over/Under (Totals)
Bet on whether the total number of goals or points scored in a game is over or under a set number.
Examples:
● Football: Over/Under 2.5 goals
● Basketball: Over/Under 180.5 points
● NFL: Over/Under 45.5 points
Parlay
The US equivalent of an accumulator. All legs must win for the bet to pay out.
Trixies, Patents, and Yankees are not parlays since they allow partial wins.
Futures (Outright Bets)
Long-term bets placed on season or tournament outcomes.
Examples:
● Premier League winner
● Wimbledon champion
● Super Bowl MVP
● Presidential election winner

overview.heading: Entertainment and Prop Bets
overview.data:
Prop Bets (Proposition Bets)
Wagers on individual events or player actions rather than the overall result.
Examples:
● First player to score
● Number of yellow cards
● Player to hit a century in cricket
These bets are especially popular for major events like the Super Bowl.

overview.heading: Specialized US Bets
overview.data:
If Bets
A two-part conditional bet:
● If Bet A wins, then Bet B is placed with the same stake.
● If Bet A loses, Bet B is never placed.
Reverse Bets
A combination of two If Bets placed in both orders. Requires placing two separate stakes.
Can result in full, partial, or no returns depending on outcomes.

overview.heading: Sport-Specific Betting Markets
overview.data:
Correct Score
Used in low-scoring sports such as football or ice hockey. Predicts the exact final score (e.g. 2–1).
Innings Runs (Cricket)
Predict how many runs a team will score in a particular innings.
Fastest Lap (Motorsports)
Bet on which driver or rider records the fastest lap during a race.
First Goalscorer / Try Scorer
Predict which player will score the first goal in football or the first try in rugby.
Winner Without (Golf/Horse Racing)
Excludes the strong favourite from betting to let you bet on who will be the best among the rest.
